document.title: 2022 K-12 Louisiana Student Standards for Social Studies

870C2310818D404285D4F73ECDC10B8C.description:
Explain important issues of the 2008 presidential election and the significance of the election of Barack
Obama.

74817EEA001D4823BDC4FEAA303B5205.description:
Analyze the presidential administrations of George H.W. Bush (Gulf War), Bill Clinton (influence of the
Contract with America on the legislative agenda, involvement in Bosnia), and George W. Bush
(September 11th).

C05292F6878247D488C1494268355CC0.description:
Compare the judicial philosophies of Supreme Court justices of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries,
including those of Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsberg.

3B185964834C442FB86149CAD2CDF41F.description:
Explain events leading up to the September 11th attacks, the attack on New York City, the attack on the
Pentagon, Flight 93, President George W. Bush’s speech from Barksdale Air Force Base, the lives lost,
national unity in the aftermath, subsequent military operations, and the expansion of intelligence
agencies.

DB23AC41B3154285A6EA5F90CF26EDD0.description:
Analyze the effects of advancements in technology and media during the mid- to late twentieth century,
including the radio, television, and the internet.

D10604A3CFC945ED9EC261070E0FB11F.description:
Explain the causes and effects of domestic incidents, terrorism, and mass shootings, including the Ruby
Ridge incident, Waco siege, Oklahoma City Bombing, and Columbine High School shooting.

EB10EC28937F4F75B8BAD829D8225EC6.description: Explain causes of the Gulf War, its major military leaders, and unity on the home-front.

07B670ECA3644C178E9B14B81B416B68.description:
Explain the effects of major issues and events of the late twentieth century, including the HIV/AIDS
epidemic and disease perceptions, the war on drugs, and the space shuttle Challenger disaster.

BF921F63EAD4441695C6D78887A5833A.description:
Analyze Ronald Reagan’s political career (“A Time for Choosing” speech) and key policies of his
presidency (four pillars of Reaganomics reduce taxes, reduce federal spending, reduce government
regulation, tighten the money supply).

4E75A2EF42474DE089DDBD8E4EBBF0BA.description: Explain major U.S. events and developments in the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries.

F265EBDDEED649C2AECD43B41303215E.description:
Explain how the failure of the communist economic and political policy, American foreign policy
pressure, and the assertion of American principles such as rights, equality, and liberty, led to the end of
the Cold War.

40E7B745A0104624B1841CE25678E359.description:
Explain factors that led to the end of the Cold War, the fall of communism, and the collapse of the Soviet
Union, including foreign policy pressures; Reagan’s “Tear Down this Wall” speech, the fall of the Berlin
Wall; glasnost and perestroika, and the decline of communism.

2815691920D04668B4C07004B199ACEC.description:
Explain the outcome and consequences of key Supreme Court decisions in the late twentieth century,
including Gideon v. Wainwright (1963), Miranda v. Arizona (1966), and Roe v. Wade (1973).

C27636E2D03C44A78A47747179757F55.description:
Explain the term "silent majority" in the context of Richard Nixon's presidency, the Watergate scandal,
his efforts to open trade with China, and his resignation.

13B89D3340AF4B2DB2E89DA26BAFEAEF.description: Analyze the role of Lyndon B. Johnson in the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War.

DD69B3C236FE47DC9E34A84BBC7F1657.description:
Analyze the effects of the campaign, election, inaugural address, presidency, and assassination of John
F. Kennedy.

CEA162338AAA4557AE0840B8159740B8.description: Explain the role of technology in the Cold War, including the Space Race, Sputnik, and Apollo 13 mission.

277E8428F78D473C90A33099FA1A5318.description:
Analyze the causes, course of, and consequences of the Cold War and its related crises and conflicts,
including the Berlin Blockade and Airlift, Chinese Civil War, Korean War, Suez Crisis, U-2 Incident, Cuban
Missile Crisis, Bay of Pigs Invasion, Vietnam War, Soviet-Afghan War, and Miracle on Ice.

6180A3C6F6BF4AA489F7CAF73EBBB4DB.description:
Describe the role of and major events and developments associated with key leaders during the Cold
War, including U.S. presidents (Harry. S. Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B.
Johnson, Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter, and Ronald Reagan); and soviet leaders (Nikita
Khrushchev and Mikhail Gorbachev).

3752C169BC484BC6B20951846AEE8760.description:
Compare ideas of the United States and Soviet Union during the Cold War, including the strengths of
American principles such as rights, equality of opportunity, liberty and equal protection under the law.

853DE733C8C04D2DB0FAB1E8F80D861C.description:
Analyze domestic policies of Dwight D. Eisenhower’s presidential administration including the Federal
Aid Highway Act of 1956.

5561DA442A4F43F08DB6D45672FE7950.description: Explain the causes and effects of the Marshall Plan and the formation of NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

26D8AFA153FC406494409F7F6388D39B.description:
Explain major events and developments of the post-World War II era in the United States and its
continued rise as a world power.

790E9069136F42A1953689A1F850EAE4.description:
Analyze the goals and course of the women’s rights movement of the mid- to late twentieth century,
with attention to House Resolution 5056, Equal Pay Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Title IX of the Education
Amendments, Equal Rights Amendment, and the advancement of women in government and various
professions.

8B9F901E4E3A47A780BE3DABE86F1086.description:
Analyze the goals and outcomes of the American Indian Movement (AIM) and the changing relationship
between Native Americans and the federal government, including before and after the Indian SelfDetermination and Education Assistance Act.

36042038C51B47B2A52FF8D3679BA094.description:
Analyze the role of the federal government in advancing civil rights, including Brown v. Board of
Education (1954), the Twenty-Fourth Amendment, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Voting Rights Act
of 1965.

961C92EAA49C48679B806131C831ED08.description:
Analyze the role and importance of key events during the civil rights movement, including the murder of
Emmett Till, Baton Rouge Bus Boycott, Montgomery Bus Boycott, Little Rock Central High School
desegregation, Greensboro Sit-Ins, Freedom Rides, demonstrations in Birmingham, 1963 March on
Washington, Freedom Summer, and Selma to Montgomery Marches.

C1114973A3474DC89A1BD973821FD42B.description:
Explain how key individuals and groups contributed to the expansion of civil rights in the United States,
including A. Philip Randolph, Jackie Robinson, Rosa Parks, Medgar Evers, Ruby Bridges, Shirley Chisholm,
John Lewis, Malcolm X, and Thurgood Marshall.

9BAC6238EE9C4978B61C44E0F2D1E97C.description:
Analyze how the ideas, work, and life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. influenced civil rights movements in
the United States, including civil disobedience, service with the Southern Christian Leadership
Conference (SCLC), writings such as his “Letter from a Birmingham Jail” and “I Have a Dream” speech,
and his assassination.

82CDB75E49614A76B9567ED3FDAFE67F.description:
Analyze the origins and goals of the civil rights movement, the effects of segregation (de jure and de
facto), and efforts to desegregate schools, transportation, and public places.

E8FF8AAAB9004ADDB8D17481D03B6E15.description: Analyze causes, major events, and key leaders of the civil rights movement.

8FA1BF0C70DA4D8983E1C4A6C31EE571.description: Describe the establishment of the United Nations, and its role in global affairs after World War II.

D4A9EF0451D34852853F7793105BA926.description:
Analyze the Holocaust, including the suspension of basic civil rights by the Third Reich, concentration
camp system, antisemitism, persecution of Jews and non-Jews, Jewish and non-Jewish resistance, the
role played by the United States in liberating Nazi concentration camps, immigration of Holocaust
survivors, and the Nuremberg trials.

8CC20DBEAD4C4B55B2AB73293B341882.description:
Explain the use of violence and mass murder as demonstrated by the Nanjing Massacre, the Holodomor,
the Holocaust, and the Bataan Death March and the treatment of U.S. prisoners of war.

A3D5195D574C4C1DBC6CACFBB33A25E4.description: Analyze the decision for and effects of dropping atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

303DBC94527344BD89811F19FC0E07CA.description:
Describe the roles of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry Truman, and the United States’ critical role in the
Allied victory.

1D103A6759494182879E933C7C7C6E12.description:
Explain the role of military intelligence, technology, and strategy during World War II including
cryptology, the Manhattan Project, island hopping and describe major battles of Midway, Normandy,
Iwo Jima, Okinawa, and Battle of the Bulge.

47B9A5C69E1743CEBF6D9C37AB8C4CBE.description:
Explain how the U.S. government managed the war effort on the home front, including campaigns to
conserve food and fuel, sale of war bonds, and coordination of wartime production.

1F4F06D8475D4847A44FC5085F64C537.description:
Explain the causes and effects of the internment of Japanese Americans in the United States during
World War II, as well as the decision in Korematsu v. United States (1944) and The Civil Liberties Act of
1988.

CB87A91ABBDF433181045C459FA31584.description:
Describe the sacrifices and contributions of American service members in the war effort including the
Tuskegee Airmen, Military Intelligence Service, 442nd Regimental Combat team, the 101st Airborne,
Women's Army Corps (WAC), Navajo Code Talkers, and the Army Signal Corps.

CAAE2B9C3FDB4163AD9FCD6AA4D1523A.description: Explain why Japan attacked Pearl Harbor and the response of the United States.

903582D8BE814F21823B642B60F86A08.description:
Explain efforts made by the U.S. government to prepare for war prior to entry including Cash and Carry
and Lend Lease policies, military maneuvers at Barksdale Air Force Base, and the Louisiana Maneuvers in
September 1941.

52456468BB3742F082BF9C36D7CEF397.description:
Explain the similarities and differences between totalitarianism and militarism in Imperial Japan,
communism in the Soviet Union, fascism in Mussolini’s Italy and Nazi Germany, and identify the major
powers of the Allies and the Axis powers.

6C95FF70B75847EC981488EADBFEBA4D.description: Explain the causes, course, and consequences of World War II.

B843FB788F6044D089AF322C545EFD5B.description:
Compare and contrast economic beliefs of Adam Smith, Karl Marx, John Maynard Keynes, and Milton
Friedman and analyze their influence on the economy of the United States.

D7AF8B47380743EF9217D73B8779D7FE.description:
Analyze the purpose and effectiveness of the New Deal in managing problems of the Great Depression
through relief, recovery, and reform programs, including the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA), Works
Progress Administration (WPA), the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), and the Social Security Act (SSA).

C76BC395AD764EB380452AD4E27CFAE2.description:
Describe the causes and effects of the Dust Bowl, including natural disasters and unwise agricultural
practices, and how it exacerbated the Great Depression.

4C27C85CD47447E187F7BC06E019CA27.description:
Analyze the government response to the Great Depression, including actions taken by the Federal
Reserve, Congress, and the administrations of Herbert Hoover and Franklin D. Roosevelt.

030867BA056448C7AD2AEEBF8DF52956.description: Describe the effects of the Great Depression.

FF2F7D23EF0A4C77A02A4D3E1EC17DCD.description:
Explain the causes of the Great Depression, with an emphasis on how bank failures, buying stock on
margin, overextension of credit, overproduction, high tariffs and protectionism, and the 1929 stock
market crash contributed to the economic crisis.

0F15F143A88C4D3CB3A8E32A3CC8FE19.description: Describe the effects of the Great Depression and New Deal policies on the United States.

6A0985A4A0F84A39AA801DD48E186D94.description:
Describe the effects of racial and ethnic tensions, including the Chicago riot of 1919, Tulsa Massacre,
and re-emergence of the Ku Klux Klan.

72AAA5B99AA64A4E89B1254CA240494E.description:
Describe Prohibition in the United States and its consequences, including the development of organized
crime.

230BA007E75D4A6899B048802C992C46.description:
Analyze the effects of changes in immigration to the United States and migration within the United
States as a result of the Immigration Act of 1924 and the Great Migration.

357C5444BBA746E297F2EFBFE99FF577.description:
Analyze the rise in labor unions in the late nineteenth century and early twentieth century including the
American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial, the Organizations (AFL-CIO), the Industrial Workers
of the World (IWW), and the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters.

BB460A8AA4CF48978413BA760EF80EE1.description:
Analyze the causes and events of the First Red Scare including the Bolshevik Revolution, anarchist
bombings, the Immigration Act of 1918, and the Palmer Raids.

CADFE5C01E76454FA6256E2875FB6CEB.description:
Analyze how life in the United States changed as a result of technological advancements, including
automobile, airplane, and radio.

8FE16058537141849C132D9A0E2FEFD9.description: Describe changes in the social and economic status of women.

485ED79840DA415FA162932E2F586288.description: Explain the origins, main ideas, contributors, and effects of the Harlem Renaissance.

1D066C90AEF5492594C236114F193BF8.description:
Analyze the political, social, cultural and economic effects of events and developments after World War I
and during the 1920s.

F8BBA1FF8026447E922D091C4EAC3F11.description: Compare and contrast Wilson’s Fourteen Points and the Treaty of Versailles.

94664E6BB99C40AA9F2CF9DAE9DCB4FE.description: Explain why the Allied Powers won World War I.

20FC48E840014EF38323E5F2C901C34B.description: Analyze the suppression of dissent during World War I.

5BCF2DA7C06B471CA26F2F87AB55245C.description:
Describe the effects of major military events, the role of key people, and the experiences of service
members.

79294D7C77014440A4FC87E9571BE488.description: Explain the events leading to and reasons for U.S. involvement in World War I.

6F63CBF009E74E24821ED2407789F959.description: Describe the causes of World War I.

451CB61D39CC4CB8ACD88A9FB177B001.description: Analyze the causes, course, and consequences of World War I.

460C780FC21A4C96BAC47F7FF16A1352.description: Analyze ways in which the Suffrage Movement led to passage of the Nineteenth Amendment.

CEB19F7BB14C44FBACB3D965F2F4EBDE.description:
Analyze the life of Susan B. Anthony, including her time teaching, work for abolition, work for
temperance, and work for suffrage.

7583475BA1994BAB96CD23CCD1720B6D.description: Explain Elizabeth Cady Stanton’s reasons for writing the Declaration of Sentiments.

4BC21AE6D37C4421B98C0049FA5356E4.description: Compare and contrast the philosophies of Booker T. Washington, W. E. B. DuBois, and Marcus Garvey.

5EF809D83A2E4606B0400ADCA0D10956.description:
Explain the origins and development of Louisiana public colleges and universities, including land grant
institutions, Historically Black Colleges and Universities, and regional universities.

D1FA99F2C78641DE9CAFB7FEEF4D72FD.description:
Analyze the life of Booker T. Washington, including his enslavement and emancipation, the Tuskegee
Institute, and his Atlanta Exposition Speech.

CACF986CCFAA434AAE63847ABE7DCFFE.description:
Describe engagements between the U.S. government forces and Native Americans in the West following
the Civil War, including the Battle of Little Bighorn and Wounded Knee, and the effects of the Dawes Act
on Native Americans.

EDFE3C9620FF4A04A79C025AB892459D.description:
Analyze the life of Theodore Roosevelt, including his life in the West, the Rough Riders, his “Big Stick”
diplomacy, presidency, and conservation efforts.

13D04BFA51B746EB953AD295501D2D6A.description:
Analyze the Monroe Doctrine, the Roosevelt Corollary, and the development of U.S. foreign policy in the
late nineteenth century and early twentieth century including the Spanish-American War, the
acquisition of Hawaii and Alaska, construction of the Panama Canal, and the U.S. expedition to capture
Pancho Villa.

B1EFB5AEF0C94433B28C4A44275D6F4B.description:
Analyze the challenges that accompanied industrialization, including pollution, poor working conditions,
child labor, and food safety, as well as proposed solutions of the Progressive Era.

56376E5D123D4B569A929442E0CA31E2.description:
Explain push and pull factors for immigration to the United States in the late nineteenth and early
twentieth century and analyze the immigrant experience, including assimilation, challenges, and
contributions.

A3A6087CF9E44A329BC41D337890A0C8.description:
Explain the economic principles and practices that corresponded with America’s industrial and economic
growth after the Civil War including free markets, capitalism, mass production, division of labor, and
monopolies.

8F02CB37B3B344628EEF2678EF192D34.description: Describe how the physical geography of the United States affected industrial growth and trade.

AB48CE583684400ABB547AFFA9066FF7.description:
Describe the economic and social development of the United States in the late nineteenth and early
twentieth century and its emergence as a major world power.

44EC97B309FD4BE0992034C0E562AB33.description:
Explain the social, political and economic changes that resulted from Reconstruction including Jim Crow
laws, the role of carpetbaggers, scalawags, Radical Republicans, the Freedmen’s Bureau, sharecropping,
the creation of Black Codes, and the emergence of the Ku Klux Klan and the rise of violence and
intimidation of Black Americans.

AA88FB80AB0A451BAFFFA23EFAAD204F.description:
Compare and contrast resources of the Union and Confederate States and reasons attributed to the
Union winning the Civil War.

33E726CBFE024D16A55A5757BBE75664.description:
Analyze major battles of the Civil War, including Shiloh, Antietam, Gettysburg, Vicksburg, and the
capture of New Orleans.

582CAD58619041B8860016FDCC39587B.description:
Explain major and minor causes of the Civil War, especially the political tension surrounding the spread
of slavery.

3C6FAC1B8F3F484AB2E7323EBFFBD30A.description:
Analyze the life of Abraham Lincoln including his debates with Stephen Douglas, the meaning of his
“House Divided” speech, presidency and views on the Union, first and second inaugural addresses, the Emancipation Proclamation, the Gettysburg Address, particularly the origin and meaning of “last full
measure of devotion,” and his assassination.

67CFE83FEA6649B09F3ABA086B9DF5B5.description: Analyze the causes, course, and consequences of the Civil War and Reconstruction.

AC525F3F82F74674928567327B7287BD.description:
Evaluate the significance and extension of citizenship rights to Black Americans included in the
Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Fifteenth Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

F48282A5174D430C9BDBA6AEB6CE569B.description: Describe the purpose of the Emancipation Proclamation and its effects.

D6EFC36B2B7B45CEBC260129F5AF7930.description: Explain the outcome of the Dred Scott v. Sandford (1857) decision, including it later being called a “selfinflicted wound.”

780786709DDE4AA8A7C61D447F96622E.description:
Analyze the causes and effects of the Missouri Compromise, the Compromise of 1850, and the Kansas
Nebraska-Act.

4FF2BD7031DA44A6B1DFBC0C305D8C3A.description: Explain how slavery is the antithesis of freedom.

470A4022443D4B95975CA779E5014891.description:
Explain the effects of abolition efforts by key individuals including Sojourner Truth, William Lloyd
Garrison, Frederick Douglass, and Harriet Beecher Stowe.

8B5B6F1271AD4E6685BE1C63493080D6.description: Explain how slavery contributed to U.S. industrial and economic growth.

1E57FD02CB21434C9D93E55F750AF3FC.description: Describe the significance of invention of the cotton gin and its effects on slavery and economy.

08A4C669EE2A4BE39184D32B12B545CC.description:
Describe the experiences of enslaved people on the Middle Passage, at slave auctions, and on
plantations.

8A0E410A0F07403ABBA25AC0D268972B.description:
Describe the origins of the transatlantic slave trade, Middle passage, and early spread of slavery in the
Americas.

9E76E1550EB54B22BF12728FCF57631B.description: Analyze the development and abolition of slavery in the United States.

6649D558CF254310803DEAC38BF8E6EC.description: Explain the concept of Manifest Destiny and evaluate its effect on Westward Expansion.

A4C436080A104571AD2F180C33A8AD7E.description: Analyze the causes and effects of the Mexican-American War.

4D3180ADD99743078F0B3372A1C920D6.description:
Analyze the causes and effects of the Indian Removal Act and describe the role of key people involved in
Indian removal and the Trail of Tears including Andrew Jackson and John Ross.

0E41951D74CD4DFC90C204B9E54333DC.description: Explain the Louisiana Purchase and evaluate its effects on the United States.

546C78158E114618BA9239B70FD1C17F.description: Analyze key events associated with Westward Expansion during the early to mid-1800s.

1849A91867844EA5AF7EF61F72E54A4A.description: Explain and evaluate the concept of American exceptionalism.

D43D6601963241BEA6B0DB96317E4361.description:
Analyze how Alexis de Tocqueville’s five values are crucial to America’s success as a constitutional
republic (liberty, egalitarianism, individualism, populism, laissez-faire).

BCD5485A9B6344C9A38DE8710AE6DDD4.description:
Analyze major events and developments of U.S. presidents of the late 1700s to the early 1800s,
including the presidencies of George Washington (foreign and domestic policies, Farewell Address), John
Adams (Alien and Sedition Act), Thomas Jefferson (role in the Louisiana Purchase), and Andrew Jackson
(Bank War).

488B81A6AD134059BDF14EACD189B728.description:
Evaluate how the U.S. Constitution and Bill of Rights seek to prevent tyranny and protect individual
liberty and freedom, including through representation, limited government, separation of powers, and
checks and balances.

1DFD0FBE75934032BA5A407EE29E3932.description: Analyze the purposes of the Preamble of the Constitution.

324BCBADD63E461CB42F946ACD965B03.description: Explain the inadequacies of the Articles of Confederation.

3F77DB8E4FD642CAA922E127B0C70E22.description:
Explain how America’s founding, based on the words of the Declaration of Independence and the U.S.
Constitution, were unprecedented in human history.

498A7C34D1C94D76A841561412502465.description:
Analyze the Declaration of Independence and evaluate how the ideas expressed reflected the values and
principles of the founders' and influenced development of the United States, with an emphasis on
“inalienable rights” as inherent in all people by virtue of their being human meaning that they cannot be
surrendered to the government; the rights to “life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness” being the
freedom to live, to protect rights, and to seek happiness as long as it does not violate the rights of
others; and the concept of “consent of the governed” and how this differed from rule under a monarch.

148C5EF5D2624297B6620A62C66AB046.description:
Explain the key reasons for the Patriots’ improbable victory and analyze major battles of the American
Revolution, including the Battle of Trenton, the Battle of Saratoga, and Yorktown.

5A10BFEA851C47CCAD96388CF4736785.description:
Explain the historical context of and the events leading to the signing of the Declaration of
Independence including the Boston Massacre, Boston Tea Party, Patrick Henry’s “Give Me Liberty or
Give Me Death” speech, the battles at Lexington and Concord and Bunker Hill, the Second Continental
Congress and failed Olive Branch Petition, and Thomas Paine’s Common Sense.

92BA77D412DD44C3978574B2F49D5F33.description:
Analyze the development of the United States from the American Revolution through the ratification of the
U.S. Constitution and Early Republic.

1A78E83A0B204DBF8FCECE623363158D.description: Compare and contrast content and viewpoints.

5841052C93964150B17B87CEDDE8BFFB.description: Demonstrate an understanding of social studies content.

A8F06A00F31346B1904BAE9C35EB12E4.description:
Construct and express claims that are supported with relevant evidence from primary and/or secondary
sources, social studies content knowledge, and clear reasoning and explanations to:

64B335178178495C87ACDA67B5B0EFC9.description: Explain how the availability of sources affects historical interpretations.

A3502643E94B4F648376BCAE83D1BAC4.description: Compare and contrast multiple sources and accounts.

6112ED3D62534522A0994E8BAD8DAE75.description: Use a variety of primary and secondary sources to:

AFEADE8973484B2DA2B0F5CA252A44CD.description:
Use geographic representations and demographic data to analyze environmental, cultural, economic and
political characteristics and changes.

BA2FF22E66A44C40AFB8EDB88BD6FB6E.description: Compare and contrast events and developments in U.S. history from 1776 to 2008.

D591CC144CF347FC9AE9B5C80F5C57DF.description:
Analyze connections between events and developments in U.S. history within their global context from
1776 to 2008.

CABBE3FA3A014F358CFB9C3DDF30B236.description:
Analyze ideas and events in the history of the United States of America from 1776 to 2008 and how they
progressed, changed, or remained the same over time.
